unnormalised: New Traffic Regulations Aim to Reduce Accidents and Improve Road Safety
normalised: New Traffic Regulations Aim to Reduce Accidents and Improve Road Safety

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26, 2023 – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has announced a comprehensive update to traffic regulations, effective November 15th. These changes aim to improve road safety and reduce the number of accidents, often attributed to negligence.
normalised: New Delhi, october twenty six, two thousand and twenty three – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has announced a comprehensive update to traffic regulations, effective november fifteenth. These changes aim to improve road safety and reduce the number of accidents, often attributed to negligence.

unnormalised: Key changes include stricter enforcement of speed limits on highways, with increased fines for exceeding the posted limits. Fines for first-time offenders could reach Rs. 5,000.
normalised: Key changes include stricter enforcement of speed limits on highways, with increased fines for exceeding the posted limits. Fines for first-time offenders could reach rupee five thousand.

unnormalised: The regulations also mandate the use of high-visibility vests for all riders of two-wheelers after dark. The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi has been instrumental in providing technical expertise for improved signage design.
normalised: The regulations also mandate the use of high-visibility vests for all riders of two-wheelers after dark. The I I T Delhi has been instrumental in providing technical expertise for improved signage design.

unnormalised: Furthermore, emphasis is placed on lane discipline, particularly on national highways like the NH44. Vehicles found weaving in and out of lanes will be penalized. Think of it like driving in "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" – smooth and predictable.
normalised: Furthermore, emphasis is placed on lane discipline, particularly on national highways like the N H fourty four. Vehicles found weaving in and out of lanes will be penalized. Think of it like driving in "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" – smooth and predictable.

unnormalised: These changes also update the "Motor Vehicles Act, 1988". The revised rules also address overloading in commercial vehicles. Authorities will be cracking down on trucks exceeding weight limits by enforcing them at all state borders, increasing penalties.
normalised: These changes also update the "Motor Vehicles Act, nineteen eighty eight". The revised rules also address overloading in commercial vehicles. Authorities will be cracking down on trucks exceeding weight limits by enforcing them at all state borders, increasing penalties.
